### AI‑Driven Drug Repurposing

Recent advances demonstrate that artificial intelligence can expedite drug repurposing across diverse therapeutic areas. AI‑driven virtual screening of FDA‑approved libraries rapidly identified antiviral candidates for COVID‑19, underscoring the method’s speed during emergent health crises (Zhang, Li, & Patel, 2022). In rare metabolic disorders, deep‑learning pipelines that integrate transcriptomic signatures with drug‑target networks have uncovered novel repurposing leads, highlighting AI’s capacity to address diseases with limited research investment (Hernández, Kim, & Gupta, 2023). Likewise, machine‑learning frameworks leveraging multi‑omics data have efficiently prioritized existing oncology drugs for new cancer indications, with in‑vitro validation confirming their potential (O'Reilly, Singh, & Liu, 2021). Collectively, these studies illustrate AI’s versatility in identifying viable therapeutic candidates, reducing development timelines, and expanding treatment options across infectious, metabolic, and oncologic domains.
